item.title: US home prices rise in May
item.description: US house prices showed their first monthly gain in three years in May offering another sign that the stricken residential real estate market is stabilising

item.title: ‘Clawback’ marks tougher SEC stance
item.description: The US Securities and Exchange Commission’s attempt to use – for the first time – a “clawback” law against an executive who is not accused of any wrongdoing marks a new hard-hitting approach at an agency under pressure to restore its reputation

item.title: High-frequency trading under scrutiny
item.description: High-frequency equity trading is under scrutiny because of concerns that it places less tech-savvy investors at a disadvantage

item.title: Fines call for Airbus and EADS executives
item.description: Seven current and former executives of Airbus and parent company EADS, including a former EADS co-chief executive, should be fined for alleged insider share dealing, according to a provisional and non-binding report prepared for the French financial markets regulator

item.title: IBM acquisition steps up software race
item.description: IBM looked set to trigger another round of consolidation race among the world’s largest makers of business software as it announced an all-cash $1.2bn acquisition of SPSS, a company whose technology is used to analyse and forecast customer and market trends

item.title: Democrats scramble for health reform
item.description: Democratic congressional leaders were scrambling to find a series of compromises on healthcare reform to satisfy their moderate – or so-called “Blue Dog” – colleagues amid intensifying concern the whole effort could get pushed back until September

item.title: BP chief warns of ‘drawn-out’ recovery
item.description: There is little evidence of any upturn in energy demand and the recovery in the world economy is likely to be “long and drawn-out”, the head of oil company BP has warned

item.title: Deutsche Bank hit by loan fears
item.description: Shares in Germany’s biggest bank tumbled 11 per cent on amid renewed fears over its exposure to the economic crisis and increased provisions against bad loans

item.title: Gates ‘heartened’ by progress on security in Iraq
item.description: Robert Gates, the US defence secretary, praised the security conditions in Iraq, almost one month after US combat troops completed their ­withdrawal from Iraqi ­cities
